Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Alexeev will work on a range of problems in algebraic geometry centering around degenerations, compact moduli spaces of stable varieties and pairs, and connections to the Minimal Model Program. Stable varieties and pairs are higher-dimensional generalizations of Deligne-Mumford-Knudsen's stable curves. Some particular subjects of this project are moduli of weighted stable hyperplane arrangements, stable surfaces of general type, and geometric meaning of various compactifications of moduli spaces of abelian varieties and K3 surfaces.

Algebraic geometry is one of most central branches of mathematics which aims to understand, both practically and conceptually, solutions of systems of polynomial equations in many variables. It has important applications to other fields of mathematics, such as number theory, topology, analysis, as well as to physics, biology, cryptography, and engineering. The particular problems that Dr Alexeev will study involve moduli spaces, a classical subject going back to Riemann, and in particular moduli spaces of stable curves and maps, and their higher-dimensional analogues. Some of these originated in physics, and may in turn find application there. The grant will contribute to training of graduate students, and will support an active program in algebraic geometry at the University of Georgia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Investigating moduli spaces of algebraic varieties has long been an important and challenging problem in algebraic geometry. Understanding them paves a path for many applications in algebraic geometry itself, as well as number theory, combinatorics, differential geometry, and other fields of mathematics. It also has major applicaitons in physics. Some important examples are the moduli spaces of curves (1-dimensional algebraic varieties) constructed in a seminal 1979 paper of Deligne-Mumford on stable curves, and the works of Kontsevich on stable maps in the 1990s.

Together with other researchers, the PI has pioneered the study in the higher-dimensional case. The generalization of Deligne-Mumford's space to higher dimensions is called the moduli space of stable varieties. It is also commonly known as the KSBA compactification, for Kollár, Shepherd-Barron, and the PI. The PI has also constructed a Kontsevich type space for stable maps from higher-dimensional varieties to arbitrary varieties. Similarly to the one-dimensional case, these moduli are expected to have major applications in other fields of mathematics and in physics.

Under this grant, the PI has continued to investigate these moduli spaces of higher dimensional stable varieties. He wrote and published a book on higher dimensional stable hyperplane arrangements, one of the more accessible examples of the general theory. He also published several papers on these moduli spaces. 

Another project completed under this grant resulted in a paper on derived categories, exceptional collections and phantoms, certain non-commutative varieties with vanishing invariants. Yet another project is an investigation of the moduli space of principally polarized abelian 6-folds, which is the subject of a famous 35 year old conjecture. Together with his coworkers, the PI has made a major advance towards the resolution of this conjecture. 

The PI worked with numerous graduate students, five of which have defended theses and went to the work force, and with postdoctoral associates. The PI gave many public lectures on his work and taught in schools for graduate students. He also co-organized two conferences in Athens, Georgia, with many participants from the South Eastern US and with major national and international speakers.
